source_paragraph: Therefore, 12a2b + 15ab2 = (3 × a × b × 2 × 2 × a) + (3 × a × b × 5 × b) = 3 × a × b × [(2 × 2 × a) + (5 × b)] = 3ab × (4a + 5b) = 3ab (4a + 5b) (required factor form) Example 2: Factorise 10x2 – 18x3 + 14x4 Solution: 10x2 = 2 × 5 × x × x 18x3 = 2 × 3 × 3 × x × x × x 14x4 = 2 × 7 × x × x × x × x The common factors of the three terms are 2, x and x
question_text: Therefore, 12a2b + 15ab2 = (3 × a × b × 2 × 2 × a) + (3 × a × b × 5 × b) = 3 × a × b × [(2 × 2 × a) + (5 × b)] = 3ab × (4a + 5b) = 3ab (4a + 5b) (required factor form) Example 2: Factorise 10x2 – 18x3 + _____x4 Solution: 10x2 = 2 × 5 × x × x 18x3 = 2 × 3 × 3 × x × x × x 14x4 = 2 × 7 × x × x × x × x The common factors of the three terms are 2, x and x

subject: Mathematics
source_paragraph: Let us write (2xy + 2y) in the factor form: 2xy + 2y = (2 × x × y) + (2 × y) = (2 × y × x) + (2 × y × 1) = (2y × x) + (2y × 1) = 2y (x + 1) Similarly, 3x + 3 = (3 × x) + (3 × 1) = 3 × (x + 1) = 3 ( x + 1) Hence, 2xy + 2y + 3x + 3 = 2y (x + 1) + 3 (x +1) Observe, now we have a common factor (x + 1) in both the terms on the right hand side
question_text: Let us write (2xy + 2y) in the factor form: 2xy + 2y = (2 × x × y) + (2 × y) = (2 × y × x) + (2 × y × 1) = (2y × x) + (2y × 1) = 2y (x + 1) Similarly, _____x + 3 = (3 × x) + (3 × 1) = 3 × (x + 1) = 3 ( x + 1) Hence, 2xy + 2y + 3x + 3 = 2y (x + 1) + 3 (x +1) Observe, now we have a common factor (x + 1) in both the terms on the right hand side

question_text: 3 Factorisation using identities We know that (a + b)_____ = a2 + 2ab + b2 (I) (a – b)2 = a2 – 2ab + b2 (II) (a + b) (a – b) = a2 – b2 (III) The following solved examples illustrate how to use these identities for factorisation

source_paragraph: So, it is of the form a2 + 2ab + b2 where a = x and b = 4 such that a2 + 2ab + b2 = x2 + 2 (x) (4) + 42 = x2 + 8x + 16 Since a2 + 2ab + b2 = (a + b)2, by comparison x2 + 8x + 16 = ( x + 4)2 (the required factorisation) Example 5: Factorise 4y2 – 12y + 9 Solution: Observe 4y2 = (2y)2, 9 = 32 and 12y = 2 × 3 × (2y) Therefore, 4y2 – 12y + 9 = (2y)2 – 2 × 3 × (2y) + (3)2 = ( 2y – 3)2 (required factorisation) Example 6: Factorise 49p2 – 36 Solution: There are two terms; both are squares and the second is negative
question_text: So, it is of the form a2 + 2ab + b2 where a = x and b = 4 such that a2 + 2ab + b2 = x2 + 2 (x) (4) + 42 = x2 + 8x + 16 Since a2 + 2ab + b2 = (a + b)2, by comparison x2 + 8x + 16 = ( x + 4)2 (the required factorisation) Example 5: Factorise 4y2 – 12y + 9 Solution: Observe 4y2 = (2y)2, 9 = _____2 and 12y = 2 × 3 × (2y) Therefore, 4y2 – 12y + 9 = (2y)2 – 2 × 3 × (2y) + (3)2 = ( 2y – 3)2 (required factorisation) Example 6: Factorise 49p2 – 36 Solution: There are two terms; both are squares and the second is negative

source_paragraph: 1 : Parallelograms on the same base and between the same parallels are equal in area
question_text: _____ : Parallelograms on the same base and between the same parallels are equal in area

subject: Mathematics
source_paragraph: In ∆ADE and ∆BCF, ∠DAE = ∠CBF (Corresponding angles from AD || BC and transversal AF) (1) ∠AED = ∠BFC (Corresponding angles from ED || FC and transversal AF) (2) Therefore, ∠ADE = ∠BCF (Angle sum property of a triangle) (3) Also, AD = BC (Opposite sides of the parallelogram ABCD) (4) So, ∆ADE ≅∆BCF [By ASA rule, using (1), (3), and (4)] Therefore, ar (ADE) = ar (BCF) (Congruent figures have equal areas) (5) Now, ar (ABCD) = ar (ADE) + ar (EDCB) = ar (BCF) + ar (EDCB) [From(5)] = ar (EFCD) So, parallelograms ABCD and EFCD are equal in area
question_text: In ∆ADE and ∆BCF, ∠DAE = ∠CBF (Corresponding angles from AD || BC and transversal AF) (1) ∠AED = ∠BFC (Corresponding angles from ED || FC and transversal AF) (_____) Therefore, ∠ADE = ∠BCF (Angle sum property of a triangle) (3) Also, AD = BC (Opposite sides of the parallelogram ABCD) (4) So, ∆ADE ≅∆BCF [By ASA rule, using (1), (3), and (4)] Therefore, ar (ADE) = ar (BCF) (Congruent figures have equal areas) (5) Now, ar (ABCD) = ar (ADE) + ar (EDCB) = ar (BCF) + ar (EDCB) [From(5)] = ar (EFCD) So, parallelograms ABCD and EFCD are equal in area

source_paragraph: In triangles PAQ and PBQ, AP = BP (Arcs of equal radii) AQ = BQ (Arcs of equal radii) PQ = PQ (Common) Therefore, ∆ PAQ ≅∆ PBQ (SSS rule) So, ∠ APM = ∠ BPM (CPCT) Now in triangles PMA and PMB, AP = BP (As before) PM = PM (Common) ∠ APM = ∠ BPM (Proved above) Therefore, ∆ PMA ≅∆ PMB (SAS rule) So, AM = BM and ∠ PMA = ∠ PMB (CPCT) As ∠ PMA + ∠ PMB = 180° (Linear pair axiom), we get ∠ PMA = ∠ PMB = 90°
question_text: In triangles PAQ and PBQ, AP = BP (Arcs of equal radii) AQ = BQ (Arcs of equal radii) PQ = PQ (Common) Therefore, ∆ PAQ ≅∆ PBQ (SSS rule) So, ∠ APM = ∠ BPM (CPCT) Now in triangles PMA and PMB, AP = BP (As before) PM = PM (Common) ∠ APM = ∠ BPM (Proved above) Therefore, ∆ PMA ≅∆ PMB (SAS rule) So, AM = BM and ∠ PMA = ∠ PMB (CPCT) As ∠ PMA + ∠ PMB = _____° (Linear pair axiom), we get ∠ PMA = ∠ PMB = 90°

question_text:
2 _____-2020 
210 MATHEMATICS This shows us that the outer surface of a cuboid is made up of six rectangles (in fact, rectangular regions, called the faces of the cuboid), whose areas can be found by multiplying length by breadth for each of them separately and then adding the six areas together

subject: Mathematics
source_paragraph: So, the sum of the areas of the six rectangles is: Area of rectangle 1 (= l × h) + Area of rectangle 2 (= l × b) + Area of rectangle 3 (= l × h) + Area of rectangle 4 (= l × b) + Area of rectangle 5 (= b × h) + Area of rectangle 6 (= b × h) = 2(l × b) + 2(b × h) + 2(l × h) = 2(lb + bh + hl) This gives us: Surface Area of a Cuboid = 2(lb + bh + hl) where l, b and h are respectively the three edges of the cuboid
question_text: So, the sum of the areas of the six rectangles is: Area of rectangle 1 (= l × h) + Area of rectangle 2 (= l × b) + Area of rectangle 3 (= l × h) + Area of rectangle 4 (= l × b) + Area of rectangle 5 (= b × h) + Area of rectangle _____ (= b × h) = 2(l × b) + 2(b × h) + 2(l × h) = 2(lb + bh + hl) This gives us: Surface Area of a Cuboid = 2(lb + bh + hl) where l, b and h are respectively the three edges of the cuboid

Mathematical Description : The formula for simple interest is I = P 100 nr , where P = Principal, n = Number of years, r % = Rate of interest I = Interest earned Here, the principal = ` 15,000 The money required by Sudhir for buying a washing machine = ` 19,000 So, the interest to be earned = ` (19,000 – 15,000) = ` 4,000 The number of years for which ` 15,000 is deposited = n The interest on ` 15,000 for n years at the rate of 8% = I Then, I = 15000 × × 8 100 n 2019-2020 
INTRODUCTION TO MATHEMATICAL MODELLING 309 So, I = 1200n (1) gives the relationship between the number of years and interest, if ` 15000 is invested at an annual interest rate of 8%
